tit.e: Inoko mochi (a rice cake imitating a little wild boar)
tit.cmt: 用語登録では「亥の子餅」は"rice cake like a little wild boar"となっています。
tit.e: Inoko mochi (a rice cake imitating a little wild boar)
Inoko mochi (a rice cake imitating a little wild boar)

sen.j: 亥の子餅（いのこもち）とは、亥の子に際して作られる餅。
sen.e: "Inoko mochi" is a rice cake cooked on inoko (the day of boar).
Inoko mochi' is a rice cake cooked on inoko (the day of boar).
Inoko mochi' is a rice cake cooked on inoko (the day of boar).

sen.j: 玄猪餅（げんちょもち）。
sen.e: It is also called "Gencho mochi."
It is also called 'Gencho mochi.'
It is also called 'Gencho mochi.'

sen.j: 亥の子（旧暦10月（亥の月）の亥の日）の亥の刻（午後10時ごろ）に食べられる。
sen.e: People eat it at inokoku (the hour of boar, or around 10:00 am) on inoko (inohi of inotsuki) (the day of boar in the month of boar or October under the old calendar).
People eat it at inokoku (the hour of boar, or around 10:00 pm) on inoko (inohi of inotsuki) (the day of boar in the month of boar or October under the old calendar).
sen.cmt: am ⇒ pm に訂正しました。
sen.e: People eat it at inokoku (the hour of boar, or around 10:00 pm) on inoko (inohi of inotsuki) (the day of boar in the month of boar or October under the old calendar).

sen.j: 俳句の季語では冬にあたる。
sen.e: It is used as kigo (a season word) of haiku (Japanese seventeen syllable poems) to represent the winter season.
It is used as kigo (a season word) of haiku (Japanese seventeen syllable poems) to represent the winter season.
It is used as kigo (a season word) of haiku (Japanese seventeen syllable poems) to represent the winter season.

sen.j: 亥の子餅を販売する菓子店があるが、新暦10月よりも旧暦10月（新暦11月）に入ってから販売されることが多い。
sen.e: Many confectioneries sell Inoko mochi in October under the old calendar (or November according to the solar calendar) rather than in October of the solar calendar.
Many confectioneries sell Inoko mochi in October under the old calendar (or November according to the solar calendar) rather than in October of the solar calendar.
Many confectioneries sell Inoko mochi in October under the old calendar (or November according to the solar calendar) rather than in October of the solar calendar.

sen.j: 名称に亥（イノシシ）の文字が使われていることから、餅の表面に焼きごてを使い、猪に似せた色を付けたものや、餅に猪の姿の焼印を押したものがある。
sen.e: Since its name includes a chinese character "亥" that means a wild boar, some Inoko mochi are colored like a bore's or marked with an image of wild boar seared on its surface by a hot branding iron.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Since its name includes a chinese character "亥" that means a wild boar, some Inoko mochi are colored like a bore's or marked with an image of wild boar seared on its surface by a hot branding iron.
Since its name includes a chinese character "亥" that means a wild boar, some Inoko mochi are colored like a bore's or marked with an image of wild boar seared on its surface by a hot branding iron.

sen.j: また、単に紅白の餅、餅の表面に茹でた小豆をまぶしたものなど、地方により大豆、小豆、ササゲ、胡麻、栗、柿、飴など素材に差異がある。
sen.e: Beside a simply colored Inoko mochi cake in red or white, there are many differently shaped and colored ones, using different materials such as soybeans, azuki beans, black-eyed peas, sesame seeds, chest nuts, persimmons, wheat glutens and so on, depending on the region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Beside a simply colored Inoko mochi cake in red or white and one covered with boiled azuki beans, there are many differently shaped and colored ones, using different materials such as soybeans, azuki beans, black-eyed peas, sesame seeds, chestnuts, persimmons, wheat glutens and so on, depending on the region.
sen.cmt: 餅の表面に茹でた小豆をまぶしたもの：訳もれです。chest nuts ⇒ chestnuts に訂正しました。
sen.e: Beside a simply colored Inoko mochi cake in red or white and one covered with boiled azuki beans, there are many differently shaped and colored ones, using different materials such as soybeans, azuki beans, black-eyed peas, sesame seeds, chestnuts, persimmons, wheat glutens and so on, depending on the region.

sen.j: このように、特に決まった形・色・材料はない。
sen.e: Thus, there is no definite shape, color or material to identify Inoko mochi.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Thus, there is no specific shape, color or material for Inoko mochi.
sen.cmt: specific for に訂正しました。
sen.e: Thus, there is no specific shape, color or material for Inoko mochi.

sen.j: 「古今要覧稿」（明治38年～40年刊行）に亥の子餅の項目があり、「蔵人式」（橘広相撰）の中に、禁中年中行事の1つとして記されている。
sen.e: According to an article in "Kokon yoranko" (an illustrated encyclopedia) publihed in 1905-1907, there had already been a description of Inoko mochi as an item for one of annual events in the Imperial court in the book of "Kuroudo-shiki" ("rules of officials in charge of classified documents") compliled by TACHIBANA no Hiromi.

According to an article in 'Kokon yoranko' (an illustrated encyclopedia) publihed in 1905-1907, there had already been a description of Inoko mochi as an item for one of annual events in the Imperial court in the book of 'Kuroudo-shiki' (rules of officials in charge of classified documents) compliled by TACHIBANA no Hiromi.

According to an article in 'Kokon yoranko' (an illustrated encyclopedia) publihed in 1905-1907, there had already been a description of Inoko mochi as an item for one of annual events in the Imperial court in the book of 'Kuroudo-shiki' (rules of officials in charge of classified documents) compliled by TACHIBANA no Hiromi.

sen.j: 橘広相は貞観_(日本)年間に存命していたことから、いつごろから、亥の子餅に関する行事が行なわれいたか定かではないが、貞観年間には宮中行事として、行なわれていたと推察される。
sen.e: Because TACHIBANA no Hiromi lived in the Jogan era (around 9th century) of the Heian period, it may be assumed that Inoko mochi cakes were cooked as an item for an Imperial ceremony in Jogan era at the latest though the time of their origin is unknown.

Because TACHIBANA no Hiromi lived in the Jogan era (around 9th century) of the Heian period, it may be assumed that Inoko mochi cakes were cooked as an item for an Imperial ceremony in Jogan era at the latest though the time of their origin is unknown.

Because TACHIBANA no Hiromi lived in the Jogan era (around 9th century) of the Heian period, it may be assumed that Inoko mochi cakes were cooked as an item for an Imperial ceremony in Jogan era at the latest though the time of their origin is unknown.

sen.j: かつては、旧暦10月・上亥日に禁裏では、亥の子餅を群臣に下賜していた。
sen.e: In the past, Inoko mochi cakes were delivered as an Imperial gift to a large number of retainers in the Imperial court on the earliest day of the wild boar days in October under old calendar.
In the past, Inoko mochi cakes were delivered as an Imperial gift to a large number of retainers in the Imperial court on the first wild boar days in October under old calendar.
sen.cmt: on the first wild boar days in October に訂正しました。
sen.e: In the past, Inoko mochi cakes were delivered as an Imperial gift to a large number of retainers in the Imperial court on the first wild boar days in October under old calendar.

sen.j: 能勢からの亥の子餅が献上されていたが、宮中においても亥の子餅が作られた。
sen.e: Inoko mochi were presented to the Emperor from Nose people, as well as cooked inside the Imperial court.
Inoko mochi were presented to the Emperor from Nose people, as well as cooked inside the Imperial court.
Inoko mochi were presented to the Emperor from Nose people, as well as cooked inside the Imperial court.

sen.j: 官職の高低により、下賜される亥の子餅の色（黒・赤・白）と包み紙の仕様に厳格な決まりがあった。
sen.e: Depending on a retainer's officiary title, the color of Inoko mochi (either black, red or white) to be given and the designs of its wrapping paper were strictly specified.
Depending on a retainer's officiary title, the color of Inoko mochi (either black, red or white) to be given and the designs of its wrapping paper were strictly specified.
Depending on a retainer's officiary title, the color of Inoko mochi (either black, red or white) to be given and the designs of its wrapping paper were strictly specified.

sen.j: 亥の子餅の色は、公卿までは黒色の餅・四品の殿上人までは赤色の餅などである。
sen.e: For example, black Inoko mochi cales were given to Court nobles or other lower ranked retainers, and red ones to such retainers as of higher ranks than Court nobles but not higher than shihonno (fourth ranked) tenjobito (courtiers allowed into Imperial Court).

For example, black Inoko mochi were given to Court nobles or other lower ranked retainers, and red ones to retainers of higher ranks than Court nobles but not higher than shihonno tenjobito (the fourth-ranked courtiers allowed into Imperial Court).
sen.cmt: cales：削除しました。such as を削除しました。shihonno tenjobito (the fourth-ranked courtiers allowed into Imperial Court)としました。
sen.e: For example, black Inoko mochi were given to Court nobles or other lower ranked retainers, and red ones to retainers of higher ranks than Court nobles but not higher than shihonno tenjobito (the fourth-ranked courtiers allowed into Imperial Court).

sen.j: また、3回にわたって、亥の子餅の下賜があったが、3度とも同じ色の餅ではなかった。
sen.e: Imperial grant of Inoko mochi was performed in three times, but different colors were adopted each time.
sen.cmt: 原文の趣旨が不明。既述の説明と矛盾しているようの思えますが、一応原文のとおりに直訳しました。
sen.e: Imperial grant of Inoko mochi was performed in three times, but colors were different each time.
sen.cmt: colors were different each time. としました。
sen.e: Imperial grant of Inoko mochi was performed in three times, but colors were different each time.

sen.j: 賞玩のために色（黒・赤・白）を変えていたという。
sen.e: It is said that they changed colors of Inoko mochi (black, red and white) each time for appreciation purpose.
It is said that they changed colors of Inoko mochi (black, red and white) each time for appreciation purpose.
It is said that they changed colors of Inoko mochi (black, red and white) each time for appreciation purpose.

tit.e: Annual Event of the Muromachi Shogunate:
Annual Event of the Muromachi Shogunate:
Annual Event of the Muromachi Shogunate:

sen.j: 室町幕府の年中行事として、旧暦10月・上亥日に亥子祝い・玄猪餅進上があった。
sen.e: The Muromachi Shogunate celebrated its annual event of Inoko-iwai or Gencho-shinjo (a celebration of little wild boars by presenting Gencho mochi) on the earliest day of boar in October under old calendar.

The Muromachi Shogunate celebrated its annual event of Inoko-iwai or Gencho-shinjo (a celebration of little wild boars by presenting Gencho mochi) on the first day of boar in October under old calendar.
sen.cmt: earliest ⇒ first に変更しました。
sen.e: The Muromachi Shogunate celebrated its annual event of Inoko-iwai or Gencho-shinjo (a celebration of little wild boars by presenting Gencho mochi) on the first day of boar in October under old calendar.

tit.e: Annual Event of the Edo Shogunate:
Annual Event of the Edo Shogunate:
Annual Event of the Edo Shogunate:

sen.j: 江戸幕府の年中行事として、亥の子を祝する行事（玄猪の祝い）があった。
sen.e: As an annual event, the Edo Shogunate held Gencho-no-iwai (a celebration of wild boars) in honor of little wild boars..
As an annual event, the Edo Shogunate held Gencho-no-iwai (a celebration of wild boars) in honor of little wild boars..
As an annual event, the Edo Shogunate held Gencho-no-iwai (a celebration of wild boars) in honor of little wild boars..

sen.j: 10月朔日（ついたち）は玄猪の祝いを行う。
sen.e: Gencho-no-iwai was held on the first day of October, every year.
Gencho-no-iwai was held on the first day of October, every year.
Gencho-no-iwai was held on the first day of October, every year.

sen.j: この日より囲炉裏を開いて、炉で鍋を焼き、火鉢で火を盛る習慣があった。
sen.e: People had a custom to put a light in irori (an open hearth), to heat a pot hung over it, and to put lighted charcoal in a brazier.
People had a custom to put a light in irori (an open hearth), to heat a pot hung over it, and to put lighted charcoal in a brazier.
People had a custom to put a light in irori (an open hearth), to heat a pot hung over it, and to put lighted charcoal in a brazier.

sen.j: 幕府では、大名・諸役人に対して、10月朔日、七つ半（午後5時）に江戸城への登城を命じ、征夷大将軍から白・赤・黄・胡麻・萌黄の5色の鳥の子餅を拝領して、戌の刻（午後7～9時）に退出する。
sen.e: At five o'clock in the evening of the first day of October, every year, the Shogunate summoned daimyo (feudal lords) and other officials to Edo-jo Castle, where seii-taishogun (literally, a great general who subdues the barbarians) gave each of them a gift of Torinoko mochi (oval rice cakes) in white, red, yellow, dark brown and light green, with which they withdrew from the castle at the hour of dog (from 7 to 9p.m.)

At five o'clock in the evening of the first day of October, every year, the Shogunate summoned daimyo (feudal lords) and other officials to Edo-jo Castle, where seii-taishogun (literally, a great general who subdues the barbarians) gave each of them a gift of Torinoko mochi (oval rice cakes) in white, red, yellow, dark brown and light green, with which they withdrew from the castle at the hour of dog (from 7 to 9p.m.)

At five o'clock in the evening of the first day of October, every year, the Shogunate summoned daimyo (feudal lords) and other officials to Edo-jo Castle, where seii-taishogun (literally, a great general who subdues the barbarians) gave each of them a gift of Torinoko mochi (oval rice cakes) in white, red, yellow, dark brown and light green, with which they withdrew from the castle at the hour of dog (from 7 to 9p.m.)

sen.j: 玄猪の祝いに参加する将軍・大名・諸役人の服装は熨斗目長裃（のしめながかみしも）と規定されている。
sen.e: The general, feudal lords and other officials who participated the Gencho-no-iwai at Edo-jo Castle were required to wear noshime-nagakamishimo (plaid long kamishimo, a kind of official wear of samurai class people).

The general, feudal lords and other officials who participated the Gencho-no-iwai at Edo-jo Castle were required to wear noshime-nagakamishimo (plaid long kamishimo, a kind of official wear of samurai class people).

The general, feudal lords and other officials who participated the Gencho-no-iwai at Edo-jo Castle were required to wear noshime-nagakamishimo (plaid long kamishimo, a kind of official wear of samurai class people).

sen.j: また、この日の夜は江戸城の本丸・西の丸の大手門・桜田門外・下乗所（げじょうしょ）に釣瓶（つるべ）式の大篝火（かがりび）が焚かれる。
sen.e: In the evening of the Gencho-no-iwai, bucket-type bonfires were lit at Honmaru (a donjon), Ote-mon Gate (a main gate) of nishinomaru (a western citadel), Sakurada-mongai (outside of Sakurada-mon Gate) and Gejousho of Edo-jo Castle.

In the evening of the day of the Gencho-no-iwai, bucket-type bonfires were lit at Honmaru (a donjon), Ote-mon Gate (a main gate) of nishinomaru (a western citadel), Sakurada-mongai (outside of Sakurada-mon Gate) and Gejousho of Edo-jo Castle.
sen.cmt: the day of を In the evening of の後ろに追加しました。
sen.e: In the evening of the day of the Gencho-no-iwai, bucket-type bonfires were lit at Honmaru (a donjon), Ote-mon Gate (a main gate) of nishinomaru (a western citadel), Sakurada-mongai (outside of Sakurada-mon Gate) and Gejousho of Edo-jo Castle.

tit.j: 摂津国能勢における亥の子餅
tit.e: Inoko mochi cakes in Nose of Settsu Province:
Inoko mochi cakes in Nose of Settsu Province:
Inoko mochi cakes in Nose of Settsu Province:

sen.j: 1870年（明治3年）まで、摂津国能勢（のせ）（現在の大阪府豊能町）にある木代村（きしろむら）・切畑村（きりはたむら）・大円村（おおまるむら）から、毎年、旧暦10月の亥の日に、宮中に亥の子餅を献上していた。
sen.e: Until 1870, Inoko mochi cakes had been presented to the Imperial Court from Kishiro, Kirihata and Omaru villages of Nose district in Settsu Province (current Toyono-cho town, Osaka Prefecture) annually on the day of boar in October under old calendar.

Until 1870, Inoko mochi cakes had been presented to the Imperial Court from Kishiro, Kirihata and Omaru villages of Nose district in Settsu Province (current Toyono-cho town, Osaka Prefecture) annually on the day of boar in October under old calendar.

Until 1870, Inoko mochi cakes had been presented to the Imperial Court from Kishiro, Kirihata and Omaru villages of Nose district in Settsu Province (current Toyono-cho town, Osaka Prefecture) annually on the day of boar in October under old calendar.

sen.j: そのことから、能勢には亥の子餅に関して以下のような伝承が伝わっている。
sen.e: This tradition was based on the following folklore about Inoko mochi, being carried down by the people of Nose district.
sen.cmt: 原文の「そのことから」の意味不明。
sen.e: This based the following folklore about Inoko mochi, being carried down by the people of Nose district.
sen.cmt: This based に訂正しました。
sen.e: This based the following folklore about Inoko mochi, being carried down by the people of Nose district.

sen.j: 仲哀天皇9年、12月に神功皇后は、自ら将帥となり、三韓に出兵した。
sen.e: In December in AD 200, Empress Jingu dispatched troops, headed by herself as a commander-in-chief, to conquest Sankan (three old Korean Kingdoms).
In December in AD 200, Empress Jingu dispatched troops, headed by herself as a commander-in-chief, to conquest Sankan (three old Korean Kingdoms).
In December in AD 200, Empress Jingu dispatched troops, headed by herself as a commander-in-chief, to conquest Sankan (three old Korean Kingdoms).

sen.j: 筑紫に還啓された後、皇太子（応神天皇）が誕生した。
sen.e: After her return to Tsukushi Province, she bore a prince (Emperor Ojin.)
After her return to Tsukushi Province, she bore a prince (Emperor Ojin.)
After her return to Tsukushi Province, she bore a prince (Emperor Ojin.)

sen.j: 仲哀天皇10年、2月に穴門・豊浦宮を出発し、群郷百僚を率いて海路をとった。
sen.e: In February in AD 201, she left Toyurano-miya Imperial Residence in Anato and took a sea route to Yamato with a troop of lords and officials under her command.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In February in AD 201, she left Toyurano-miya Imperial Residence in Anato and took a sea route to Yamato with a troop of lords and officials under her command.
In February in AD 201, she left Toyurano-miya Imperial Residence in Anato and took a sea route to Yamato with a troop of lords and officials under her command.

sen.j: 大和に凱旋する途中に、皇太子の異母兄である香阪（かごさか）・忍熊（おしくま）の二王子が、やがて皇太子が即位することを嫉（ねた）んだ。
sen.e: On her triumphant return to Yamato, Kagosaka and Oshikuma, the older paternal half brothers of the newly born prince, felt envy at anticipated ascension of the new prince to the crown in future.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On her triumphant return to Yamato, Kagosaka and Oshikuma, the older paternal half brothers of the newly born prince, felt envy at anticipated ascension of the new prince to the crown in future.
On her triumphant return to Yamato, Kagosaka and Oshikuma, the older paternal half brothers of the newly born prince, felt envy at anticipated ascension of the new prince to the crown in future.

sen.j: 二王子が相謀り、皇太子を迎え討って殺害しようと大軍を率いた。
sen.e: The two princes, stepchildren of Empress Jingu, conspired together to kill their half brother, and headed a large army against him.
The two princes, stepchildren of Empress Jingu, conspired together to kill their half brother, and headed a large army against him.
The two princes, stepchildren of Empress Jingu, conspired together to kill their half brother, and headed a large army against him.

sen.j: 上陸するのを待つ間、戦の勝敗を卜（ぼく）して（占って）、能勢（大阪府）の山に入り、「祈狩」（うけいがり）を催した。
sen.e: While waiting for arrival and landing of their enemy, they entered into a mountain in Nose district (Osaka Prefecture) and held "Ukeigari" (prayers for fortune-telling) to augur their victory or defeat in the coming battle.

While waiting for arrival and landing of their enemy, they entered into a mountain in Nose district (Osaka Prefecture) and held 'Ukeigari' (prayers for fortune-telling) to augur their victory or defeat in the coming battle.

While waiting for arrival and landing of their enemy, they entered into a mountain in Nose district (Osaka Prefecture) and held 'Ukeigari' (prayers for fortune-telling) to augur their victory or defeat in the coming battle.

sen.j: 「戦に勝つならば、良獣を獲られるであろう」と言っていた。
sen.e: "If you are destined to win the battle, you may get a good animal," they were told.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: If you are destined to win the battle, you may get a good animal,' they were told.
If you are destined to win the battle, you may get a good animal,' they were told.

sen.j: まもなく、大イノシシが現われれ、香阪王に飛び掛った。
sen.e: But, after a short time, a big wild boar appeared in front of prince Kagosaka and jumped on him.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 また、既述の「香阪王子」がなぜ「香阪王」に変わっているのか、不明。ここでは「香阪王子」と読み替えて訳しました。
sen.e: After a short time, a big wild boar appeared in front of prince Kagosaka and jumped on him.
After a short time, a big wild boar appeared in front of prince Kagosaka and jumped on him.

sen.j: 香阪王は驚いて、近くの大樹によじ登ったが、猪は大樹の根を掘り起こし、遂に香阪王は死亡した。
sen.e: In surprise, prince Kagosaka climbed on a nearby big tree, but the wild boar dug out the root of the tree and finally killed him.
In surprise, prince Kagosaka climbed on a nearby big tree, but the wild boar dug out the root of the tree and finally killed him.
In surprise, prince Kagosaka climbed on a nearby big tree, but the wild boar dug out the root of the tree and finally killed him.

sen.j: 忍熊王はこの事を聞き、怪しみ恐れて、住吉に軍勢を退いた。
sen.e: Being told of the boar that killed Prince Kosaka, Prince Oshikuma wondered about and feared of the boar so much that he retreated his army to Sumiyoshi.
sen.cmt: 「忍熊王」についても、「香阪王」同様、「忍熊王子」と読み替えて訳しました。
sen.e: Being told of the boar that killed Prince Kosaka, Prince Oshikuma wondered about and feared of the boar so much that he retreated his army to Sumiyoshi.
Being told of the boar that killed Prince Kosaka, Prince Oshikuma wondered about and feared of the boar so much that he retreated his army to Sumiyoshi.

sen.j: 神功皇后はこの事を聞かれて、武内宿禰に忍熊王を討伐を命じた。
sen.e: Being informed of the retreat of Prince Oshikuma, Empress Jingu ordered TAKENOUCHI no Sukune to subdue Prince Oshikuma.
Being informed of the story, Empress Jingu ordered TAKENOUCHI no Sukune to subdue Prince Oshikuma.
sen.cmt: retreat of Prince Oshikuma ⇒ story に変更しました。
sen.e: Being informed of the story, Empress Jingu ordered TAKENOUCHI no Sukune to subdue Prince Oshikuma.

sen.j: 忍熊王は戦に破れ、山城国宇治市に退き、さらに近江国瀬田に逃れたが、死亡した。
sen.e: Prince Oshikuma lost the battle, withdrew to Uji City of Yamashiro Province and further to Seta of Omi Province and finally died.
Prince Oshikuma lost the battle, withdrew to Uji City of Yamashiro Province and further to Seta of Omi Province and finally died.
Prince Oshikuma lost the battle, withdrew to Uji City of Yamashiro Province and further to Seta of Omi Province and finally died.

sen.j: これにより、皇后・皇太子は、無事に大和の都に凱旋した。
sen.e: After these events, Empress Jingu and her prince returned in glory to the capital city Yamato.
After these events, Empress Jingu and her prince returned in glory to the capital city Yamato.
After these events, Empress Jingu and her prince returned in glory to the capital city Yamato.

sen.j: その後、神功皇后が崩御し、皇太子（応神天皇）が即位した。
sen.e: Since then, Empress Jingu deceased and her prince (Emperor Ojin) assumed the throne.
Later, Empress Jingu deceased and her prince (Emperor Ojin) assumed the throne.
sen.cmt: Since then ⇒ Laterに訂正しました。
sen.e: Later, Empress Jingu deceased and her prince (Emperor Ojin) assumed the throne.

sen.j: 応神天皇は、皇太子の時に、猪に危難を救われた事を思い出して、吉例として、詔を発して、能勢・木代村、切畑村、大円村より、毎年10月の亥の日に供御を行うように命じ、亥の子餅の献上の起源であると言い伝えらえれている。
sen.e: Emperor Ojin, who remembered the boar that had saved him from danger when he was a prince, issued an imperial edict to make it a festive custom for the people of Kishiro, Kirihata and Omaru villages in Nose district to present kugo (emperor's meal) on the day of boar in October every year, which is now believed to be the origin of the custom to present Inoko mochi cakes of Nose district to Imperial court.

Emperor Ojin, who remembered the boar that had saved him from danger when he was a prince, issued an imperial edict to make it a festive custom for the people of Kishiro, Kirihata and Omaru villages in Nose district to present kugo (emperor's meal) on the day of boar in October every year, which is now believed to be the origin of the custom to present Inoko mochi cakes of Nose district to Imperial court.

Emperor Ojin, who remembered the boar that had saved him from danger when he was a prince, issued an imperial edict to make it a festive custom for the people of Kishiro, Kirihata and Omaru villages in Nose district to present kugo (emperor's meal) on the day of boar in October every year, which is now believed to be the origin of the custom to present Inoko mochi cakes of Nose district to Imperial court.

sen.j: 能勢から、宮中へ献上される亥の子餅（能勢餅（のせもち）とも言う）（近世ごろ）の調理方法が「禁裏献上 能勢のおいの子」に記載されている。
sen.e: Cooking process of Inoko mochi cakes (also called Nose-mochi) to be presented to the Imperial Court from Nose district in the early modern times was then referred to in the description "Kinri Kenjo Nose no Oinoko" (Nose's rice cakes presented to the Imperial Court).

Cooking process of Inoko mochi cakes (also called Nose-mochi) to be presented to the Imperial Court from Nose district in the early modern times was then referred to in the description 'Kinri Kenjo Nose no Oinoko' (Nose's rice cakes presented to the Imperial Court).

Cooking process of Inoko mochi cakes (also called Nose-mochi) to be presented to the Imperial Court from Nose district in the early modern times was then referred to in the description 'Kinri Kenjo Nose no Oinoko' (Nose's rice cakes presented to the Imperial Court).

sen.j: 10月に入ると、猪子役人の当番の者が御所御賄所に出頭し、御用の数を伺う、「合数伺い」を行う。
sen.e: At the beginning of October, inoko-yakunin (an official in charge of Inoko festival) on duty presented himself at a catering section of the Imperial Court and made a ritual "Gosu-ukagai" to ask how many number of go (a unit of quantity) of Inoko mochi were required.

At the beginning of October, inoko-yakunin (an official in charge of Inoko festival) on duty presented himself at a catering section of the Imperial Court and made a ritual 'Gosu-ukagai' to ask how many number of go (a unit of quantity) of Inoko mochi were required.

At the beginning of October, inoko-yakunin (an official in charge of Inoko festival) on duty presented himself at a catering section of the Imperial Court and made a ritual 'Gosu-ukagai' to ask how many number of go (a unit of quantity) of Inoko mochi were required.

sen.j: この時に、御賄所より、その数（合数）を記した御書付を下される「御書下げ」があり、調理準備に入る。
sen.e: Then, the catering section would make a ritual "gosho sage" to render a description of order quoting the number of go (a unit of quantity) of Inoko mochi to be submitted, according to which Inoko mochi for the Imperial Court were prepared..

Then, the catering section would make a ritual 'gosho sage' to render a description of order quoting the number of go (a unit of quantity) of Inoko mochi to be submitted, according to which Inoko mochi for the Imperial Court were prepared.
sen.cmt: " " ⇒ ' ' に訂正しました。ピリオドをひとつ削除しました。
sen.e: Then, the catering section would make a ritual 'gosho sage' to render a description of order quoting the number of go (a unit of quantity) of Inoko mochi to be submitted, according to which Inoko mochi for the Imperial Court were prepared.

sen.j: 1合とは、1箱のことである。
sen.e: One go (a unit of quantity) meant one box.
One go (a unit of quantity) meant one carton.
One go (a unit of quantity) meant one carton.

sen.j: 献上の数は一定していないが、約100合から150合である。
sen.e: The quantity of Inoko mochi to be presented to the Imperial Court annually was not fixed, but it stood in a range from about one hundred to one hundred and fifty goes (boxes).
The quantity of Inoko mochi to be presented to the Imperial Court annually was not fixed, but it stood in a range from about one hundred to one hundred and fifty goes (cartons).
The quantity of Inoko mochi to be presented to the Imperial Court annually was not fixed, but it stood in a range from about one hundred to one hundred and fifty goes (cartons).

sen.j: 亥の日7日前になると、献上する亥の子餅を作る家には、亥の子餅を調理する場所・道具・使用する井戸を木代村では、真言宗・善福寺（どんどろ大師善福寺）、切畑村は法華宗・法性寺の僧侶を請じて、それぞれ清めの加持を行った後に調理が始まる。
sen.e: On the day, seven days prior to the day of boar, each house preparing Inoko mochi cakes for the Imperial Court had invited monks of either Zenpuku-ji Temple of Shingon sect (also called Dondoro Taishi Zenpuku-ji) in Kishiro village or Hossho-ji Temple of Hokke sect in Kirihata village in order to hold an incantation to purify the places, instruments and wells for cooking of Inoko mochi, in advance of commencing their cooking process.

On the day, seven days prior to the day of boar, each house preparing Inoko mochi cakes for the Imperial Court had invited monks of either Zenpuku-ji Temple of Shingon sect (also called Dondoro Taishi Zenpuku-ji) in Kishiro village or Hossho-ji Temple of Hokke sect in Kirihata village in order to hold an incantation to purify the places, instruments and wells for cooking of Inoko mochi, in advance of commencing their cooking process.

On the day, seven days prior to the day of boar, each house preparing Inoko mochi cakes for the Imperial Court had invited monks of either Zenpuku-ji Temple of Shingon sect (also called Dondoro Taishi Zenpuku-ji) in Kishiro village or Hossho-ji Temple of Hokke sect in Kirihata village in order to hold an incantation to purify the places, instruments and wells for cooking of Inoko mochi, in advance of commencing their cooking process.

sen.j: 糯米（もちごめ）を洗い清めて、水に浸す。
sen.e: Wash, purify and souse glutinous rice in water.
Wash, purify and souse glutinous rice in water.
Wash, purify and souse glutinous rice in water.

sen.j: 蒸篭（せいろう）に入れて、糯米を蒸す。
sen.e: Then, put the glutinous rice in seiro (a bamboo steamer) and steam it.
Then, put the glutinous rice in seiro (a bamboo steamer) and steam it.
Then, put the glutinous rice in seiro (a bamboo steamer) and steam it.

sen.j: 別に小豆（あずき）を蒸した糯米に合せる。
sen.e: Prepare azuki beans separately, and mix them with the steamed rice.
sen.cmt: 原文の「別に小豆（あずき）を蒸した糯米に合わせる」を「別に蒸した小豆（あずき）を蒸した糯米にあわせる」と読みなおして訳しました。
sen.e: Prepare azuki beans separately, and mix them with the steamed rice.
Prepare azuki beans separately, and mix them with the steamed rice.

sen.j: 合せた糯米を挺樋（ねりおけ）と呼ばれる四斗樽の樋に投じて2本の棒を用いて「エイエイ」と掛声をしながら、こねつける。
sen.e: Throw the steamed rice mixed with azuki beans into a tub called "nerioke" that is shaped like shitodaru (a barrel of four-to or about 72-liters), and knead them by two sticks calling out "Ei Ei."
Throw the steamed rice mixed with azuki beans into a tub called "nerioke" that is shaped like shitodaru (a barrel of four-to or about 72-liters), and knead them by two sticks calling out "Ei Ei."
Throw the steamed rice mixed with azuki beans into a tub called "nerioke" that is shaped like shitodaru (a barrel of four-to or about 72-liters), and knead them by two sticks calling out "Ei Ei."

sen.j: やがて、淡紅色の猪の色に似た餅が出来る。
sen.e: Then before long, sticky rice colored in boar's rose-pink is made.
Then before long, sticky rice colored in boar's rose-pink is made.
Then before long, sticky rice colored in boar's rose-pink is made.

sen.j: 長さ6寸・幅４寸・深さ1寸5分の箱に餅を詰め、別に煮た小豆の釜に沈殿した餡を流しかける。
sen.e: Pack the rice cakes in a box of about 18cm length, about 12cm width and about 4.5cm depth, and pour onto the cakes the remnant paste of azuki beans that had been left in the kiln after boiling azuki beans.

Pack the rice cakes in a box of about 18cm length, about 12cm width and about 4.5cm depth, and pour onto the cakes the remnant paste of azuki beans that had been left in the kiln after boiling azuki beans.

Pack the rice cakes in a box of about 18cm length, about 12cm width and about 4.5cm depth, and pour onto the cakes the remnant paste of azuki beans that had been left in the kiln after boiling azuki beans.

sen.j: 餡を流しかけた餅の上に、薄く切った方形に切ったクリの実を6個並べ、その上に更に、熊笹の葉2枚で覆う。
sen.e: Put on the rice cakes and azuki bean pastes six pieces of chestnut cut in a thin square shape, and further cover them all by two leaves of kumazasa (veitch's bamboo).
Put six pieces of chestnut cut in a thin square shape on the rice cakes and azuki bean pastes, and further cover them all by two leaves of kumazasa (veitch's bamboo).
sen.cmt: 前半の語順を訂正しました。
sen.e: Put six pieces of chestnut cut in a thin square shape on the rice cakes and azuki bean pastes, and further cover them all by two leaves of kumazasa (veitch's bamboo).

sen.j: 餅は猪肉、栗は猪の骨、熊笹は牙を模しているという。
sen.e: It is said that each rice cake is an imitation of boar meats, while chestnuts and kumazasa imitate boar's bones and fangs respectively.
It is said that each rice cake is an imitation of boar meats, while chestnuts and kumazasa imitate boar's bones and fangs respectively.
It is said that each rice cake is an imitation of boar meats, while chestnuts and kumazasa imitate boar's bones and fangs respectively.
